intro: Hemicarpurus fornicatus, commonly known as the sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Geraniaceae family and is characterized by its erect, branching stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its leaves are usually opposite and covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss. Hemicarpurus fornicatus produces small, pink or white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer.
